variants.Description in input context: The A30P mutation decreases lipid affinity relative to wild-type RS and is associated with increased toxicity due to elevated SL1 binding mode.
The E46K mutation increases lipid binding relative to wild-type RS and is associated with increased toxicity due to elevated SL1 binding mode.
The A53T mutation has comparable lipid affinity to wild-type RS but is associated with increased toxicity due to elevated SL1 binding mode.

Functional Impact: These mutations alter lipid binding properties and promote the formation of disease-associated oligomers and fibrils, contributing to Parkinson's disease.
Additional Notes: The mutations A30P, E46K, and A53T in R-synuclein are associated with familial forms of Parkinson's disease.
